millisecond latency at all times and consistency in performance is super key in today's world that because once you
see a smaller service you know that users are just going to move move over to something that's much more faster
right so the other other aspect also worth noting is that Dynamo DB
automatically replicates your data across three availability zones so what
does it mean is when you make a write your data is written into a Master Copy
and it's also replicated twice the call that you make to write write it to the master Master replicates it to one of
the replicas and then returns while the other replica is you know written
asynchronously so now when you make a read you have two choices you can say I need a strongly consistent read in which
case it's going to hit the master node and say okay give me the Master Copy give me the latest value or you can go
the eventually consistent route and you can say hey just give me the data from any one of the replicas as fast as
possible so yes eventual consistency is going to provide you some a little bit more faster performance as opposed to
strong consistency but it's option that you can choose it's a parameter that you can pass in the API and it's up to you
how you want to utilize it now internally though how does Dynamo DB operate so as I mentioned it's a no SQL
data store so there's no schema as such so at a simplest level consists of tables tables consist of rows that we
call items and items consist of different columns or attributes since it
doesn't have a schema you know your columns your attributes don't have to be the same they don't have to be the same
in Number the only thing that you need is you need a unique value which we call the hash ID or the item key to actually

now I'm sure you might be wondering hey oh that sounds good but how exactly do you provision it how many nodes do you

Aurora Aurora uses a distributed storage layer and hence it's able to scale much more
better than the other databases it automatically scales the storage your data is replicated six times across
three different availability zones it can scale up to 64 terabytes of data and it can support up to 15 replicas and
it's five times more faster than MySQL Aurora is fully compatible with mySQL and so if you're considering a

provides you a guaranteed performance you can specify the level of input output operations that you need from

olp use cases uh you know where performance matters a lot and so you need consistent performance you can use

would automatically fail over to the other that way guaranteeing you high

constitutes RE shift so basically you have a leader node which is responsible
to be your SQL end point it is also going to coordinate your query execution across a bunch of compute nodes so it's
a massively parallel system and so you can have a lot many compute notes who are all going to do your query execution
in parallel they're also going to do do your data loading in parallel from various data sources like Dynamo DB S3
EMR and so on the two data storage options you have a hard disk option and
you have a SSD option again you can pick the one that you want depending on the performance and the cost factors that
you feel are more applicable to your businesses now the big part of red shift
compared to all the other systems is its speed what makes it faster you know why is it that other systems are not that
fast the biggest thing is it's architected that way so that there's a lot more optimization for Speed first of
all red shift has a columnar data store so essentially when you make queries around columns since it's stored in a
columnar fashion it's much more faster also aggregation for example here if you want to aggregate on the amount column
because it's stored together it's easier to aggregate you don't have to read through the whole row one after the other also red shift offers data
compression so since it's stored as a column the like data types in the same column so it can easily compress it it
also Al utilizes zone maps where you can have a Min and max value for the various blocks to identify which blocks are
applicable for your query and skip over the others it also supports large data blocks and direct attached storage so
the block size that red shift uses is around 1 MB and comparatively the traditional systems use around 2 KB to
32 KB block sizes so with such a big size you reduce the total number of IO you know requests that you need and that
way you get a lot more performance another part to note is that you know it supports full continuous and
incremental backups so your data is not just replicated within the cluster it
also can be you know uh backed up to S3 incrementally you can also back it up
across regions and so if there is any disaster in one region you always have the option to come back so talking about
disaster and failures so there are you know red shift is built to be fall tolerant so if a dis fails it's going to
immediately pull up a separ a separate copy of that disc which which is in the cluster and it's going to bring up a new
dis in it in the place of the older dis in the meantime if a whole node fails it's going to bring up a new node uh and
you know the data is not lost you have other replicas in the same cluster so you can continue operating if there's a network failure or even if there's an a
level failure you can set up your backups you know such that you can actually you know revert back to a cross
region replica of of the data in S3 you you always have the option to handle it
you know how well you want in terms of there is any failure in any place that level of flexibility is provided to you
by Red shift coming to the pricing part again it's the same story you pay for
what you use you pick the instances that you want your leader node is free you only pay for the compute nodes that you
